body.p:
Columbus, O, Octr 11th, 1862.
His Excellency J. F. Robinson, governor of Kentucky --

Dear Sir -- pardon me for again intruding on your attention. But "all that a man hath will he give for his life." Judge Hichcock, special comr from Washington, has considered my case, and he recommended my release to the War Department, with the endorsement of Governor Tod -- In consideration of which, and my greatly infeebeld health, I have been paroled to this city, for ten days -- I feel fully satisfide that the Department will affirm the Decision of the Judge; but it may be delayed beyond the peariod of my parole, which expires on the 18th Govenr Tod has the right, I learn, to extend paroles -- Will you do me the favor to requrest govr Tod, should it become necessary, to extend my parole, and not permit me to be sent back to prison? An other weeks confinement and exposure in that place will terminate my earthly existence. I am anxious to get Home and die in the bosom of my the little remnant of my once hapy, but now deeply affected family.

Very truly and respectfully,
Edward Stevenson
